L2_gloss: A tropical fruit tree native to South America (Campomanesia
Surinam cherry (fruit of the Eugenia uniflora tree)
village, especially a typical Brazilian indigenous
village, especially a typical Brazilian indigenous

man, especially a Brazilian male Indian.
Abá peró supé o-nhe'eng.The Indians talked to the Portuguese.

bat, common name to certain chiropteran mammals
José de Anchieta, Teatro:
Andyrá ruãpe é, panama koîpó gûaîkuíka?Is it a bat, a butterfly or a cuica?
Name of a supernatural being of Tupi Mythology.

(transitive) to singe; to burn the feathers or bristles of.
1999,  José de Anchieta,  Teatro de Anchieta (play, in Portuguese), São Paulo: Editora Martins Fontes, page 162:Xe posaká, xe ratã; oroapek; oroesyne…I am valiant, I am strong; I will singe you; I will roast you…
Any of a number of Brazilian trees or the pear-like, apple-shaped guava fruits they bear, of species Psidium cattleyanum or Psidium guineense or another species of Psidium, or Eugenia stipitata.
A tropical fruit tree native to South America (Annona crassiflora).
blowfish (any species of fish of the family Tetraodontidae that have the ability to inflate themselves to a globe)

(intransitive) to fly
José de Anchieta, Teatro:
Ybytyrybo gûibebébo, asó tupi moangaîpapa.Flying through the mountains, I went to make the Tupi sin.
José de Anchieta, Teatro:
Irõ, xe îar, abebé.There, my lord, I flew.
José de Anchieta, Poems:
Obebé îandé suí.It flies away from us..

death
1618, Araújo (Antônio de), Catecismo na Língua Brasílica, Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio de Janeiro (Rio, 1952), page 315:
Opá t-eõ îandé mo-ndyk-i.
Death destroys us all.
A land; a region; a place; a country.
The fruit of the plant Campomanesia xanthocarpa
(intransitive) to war, to engage in conflit
combining form of gûasu (“big”) (after a word ending in a stressed vowel).

(intransitive) to walk
abá o-gûatá
the man walks

to differ; to be different
Oré nhe'enga o-îkoé-eté.Our language is very different.

to live, reside
Kunhã-porang-a oré tá-pe o-ikó.The beautiful woman lives in our village.
caatinga (sparse, thorny wooded area of northeastern Brazil)

to have lunch; to eat
Ere-karuYou eat.
funk (foul or unpleasant smell, especially body odour)

good
Akûeî kunhã i katu.That woman is good.
grumichama (A tropical fruit tree native to South America (Eugenia brasiliensis)

woman, especially an indigenous woman from the Americas
XVI century, Anchieta, Poesias tupis (São Paulo, 1941):
Amó kunhã suí i mo-ingó-é-bo.
He made a woman different from any other.

boy
Ebokûeî kunumĩ i nde membyra.That boy is your son.
Copoasu, a tropical fruit tree native to South America (Theobroma grandiflorum).
Name of a supernatural entity of Tupi Mythology, inhabitant of the forests, that had the feet turned backwards.

burrow; den; hole
Pe-sem tatu kûara suí.You got out of the armadillo's burrow.
the Sun, Guaraci, the Sun personified.
margay, and similar species, such as the oncilla and the ocelot.
wise, learned, Leonardo do Vale, Vocabulário na Língua
a myth from the ancient Brazilian indigenous peoples.

snake.
José de Anchieta,  Poemas: lírica portuguesa e tupi, poems from the 16th century, organized and translated by Eduardo de A. Navarro, São Paulo: Martins Fontes, published 2004, page 178:Eva, îandé sy-ypy,o-nhe-momotar-etéybá-poranga r-esé,mboîa nhe’enga r-upi,i-î yky-é-’bo, i gû-abo nhẽ.Eva, our first mother,was much attractedby the beautiful fruit,after the snake’s words,and indeed picking it, and eating it.
moriche palm (Mauritia flexuosa, a palm of tropical South America)
cacique, chieftain; an Indian chief, in a tribe.

ear.
1618,  Antônio de Araújo,  Catecismo na Lingoa Brasilica no qual se contem a summa da doctrina christã, Lisboa: Pedro Crasbeeck, page 54b:S. Pedro y tãgapema ocequij morubixàba rembiauçuba Malco ceribaè ra pixapa, ynambi mondôra [sic].S. Pedro itangapema osekyî, morubixaba rembîaûsuba Malco séryba’e rapixapa, i nambi mondoka.Saint Peter drew his sword, striking a servant of the high priest called Malchus, cutting off his ear.

to run
Abá o-nhan.The man runs.
rhea (bird), especially the Greater Rhea (Rhea americana).

to speak, to talk
Peró supé oro-nhe'eng.We talked to the Portuguese.

language
Oré nhe'enga o-îkó-eté.Our language is very different.

typical Brazilian indigenous housing
XVI century, Anchieta, Auto de S. Lourenço (São Paulo, 1948):
E-îor-í i-mo-sykyîé-bo, t-o-ikó umé oka r-upi oré anga mo-ngué-bo.
Come to scare them away, so that they may be no longer in our houses corrupting our souls.

to arrive by water
Ygarusu-etá o-îepotar.Many ships arrived.

paca (rodent of genus Cuniculus)
Paka o-nhanThe paca ran.

Used to indicate location, inclusion, or position within spatial limits.
in, on, to.
Caryocar brasiliense, a tree native to the Brazilian cerrado
A person native to Portugal, Portuguese

second-person plural personal pronoun; you
Peẽ pe-gûapyk. ― You sat.
the sudden burst of a surface, popcorn
(cosmological) The land without evil; a myth that was
(Tupian cosmology) A mythical land free from evil.
a kind of plant whose stems were used as fishing rods,
Arapaima gigas, a species of freshwater fish native
piranha. Any of the carnivorous freshwater fish living

beautiful
Kunhã i porang.The woman is beautiful.

to stay (at)
Peró-etá ygarusu pupé o-pytá.Many Portuguese stayed inside the ships.
thrush (any species of songbirds of the genus Turdus)
marmoset (any of several species of small, long-tailed monkeys)

to exit; to leave; to get out
A-sem 'y suí.I got out of the water.
name of a entity from Tupi mythology that would have taught agriculture to the natives.

to (dative)
Morubixab-etá supé pe-nhe'eng.You talked to many caciques.

to arrive
Ka'a-pe a-syk.I arrived at the forest.

to fear, to be afraid
Abá-etá o-sykyîé.Many Indians were afraid.
swimming crab, especially the large ones with a pair

to go
'Y kûá-pe a-só.I go to the cove.
Name of a supernatural being of Tupi Mythology.

anteater
1999,  José de Anchieta,  Teatro de Anchieta (play, in Portuguese), São Paulo: Editora Martins Fontes, page 62:Akó xe îubykarûera, tataûrana, tamandûá…!That is the one who strangled me, a stinging caterpillar, an anteater!
A carnivorous freshwater fish from South American rivers (Hoplias malabaricus).
moth caterpillar with stinging hair, 1999,  José de
toucan (any bird from the family Ramphastidae)
Brother of one's mother. Maternal uncle.
Achiote (Bixa orellana), a shrub native to a region between northern South America and Mexico.
combining form of gûasu (“big”) (after a word ending in a consonant or unstressed vowel).

tree, wood
Luís Figueira, Arte de grammatica da lingua brasilica (1621):
Aybyrá-'ab.I cut the tree.

ship.
Peró-etá ygarusu pupé o-pytá.Many Portugueses stayed inside the ships.
any tortoise (terrestrial turtle) from the genus Chelonoidis.

alligator
Îakaré 'y suí o-sem.The alligator got out of the river.

to arrive by water
Ygarusu-etá o-îepotar.Many ships arrived.
any bird from the genus Leptotila.

mouth.
1614,  Claude d'Abbeville,  Histoire de la mission des pères capucins en l’isle de Maragnan et terres circonvoisines, Paris, page 350:Deierou peignote moan erereco [sic].Nde îurupe nhõtemo ã ererekó.You only have that in your mouth (not in practice).
Name of a trickster or demon from Tupian mythology.,
